awd_titl_txt: Canisius Science Scholars: Providing an Integrated Academic and Social Support Scaffolding in the Biological Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
The S-STEM project at Canisius College will help academically-talented, financially-needy Biology, Environmental Science, and Animal Behavior, Ecology and Conservation (ABEC) majors make the transition from science students to scientists. The Canisius Science Scholars program will improve recruitment, retention, graduation rates, and entry into STEM careers for both traditional and transfer students pursuing undergraduate degrees in the biological sciences at Canisius College. To achieve these goals, the S-STEM scholarship recipients will participate in a biology-based learning community. Students will benefit from shared courses that help build skills and establish commitment to STEM fields; special events that they help plan; access to scientists who serve as advisors, models, teachers, and mentors; and opportunities to socialize and celebrate their academic and career-focused accomplishments. The success of the learning community and its components will be presented at STEM, social science, and/or educational conferences and will be shared broadly to provide wider application of successful initiatives to STEM education.

The goals of the Canisius Science Scholars program are: 1) to recruit and retain additional students in the biological sciences, especially seeking to provide aid to those that transfer from other institutions, 2) build an active learning community across these students' course of studies, 3) increase the focus on assisting transfer students to adapt to the increased expectations of a 4-year biological sciences program, and 4) provide all these students with the necessary skills to enter the work-force directly or to prepare for graduate school. This program will increase student support systems and educational opportunities through enhanced academic support, career counseling, a transfer initiative including academic support and mentoring, seminar courses that provide professional skills and scientific training, and conference travel. Students will learn to be scientists through a variety of activities that encourage them to think critically about science, including involvement in research with faculty and critiquing scientific publications and presentations. As part of the program. Successful/impactful program components will be permanently incorporated into the curriculum, making them available to all future students. The presentation of the resulting scholarship on campus, at discipline-specific conferences, and in appropriate science education journals will allow others to incorporate successful individual program components into their own programs

inst.inst_name: CANISIUS UNIVERSITY OF BUFFALO NEW YORK
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: CANISIUS UNIVERSITY OF BUFFALO NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The recruitment, retention, and graduation of undergraduate science majors are critical to developing a strong STEM workforce. Along these lines, 35 total students were provided scholarships, mentoring, and opportunities for research through the NSF S-STEM-sponsored, Canisius College (now Canisius University) Science Scholars Program. The students in the Scholars Program were spread across four cohorts, with eight students in Cohort #1, twelve in Cohort #2, eight in Cohort #3, and seven in Cohort #4. Twenty-three of the Science Scholars entered the program as second-year undergraduates and were supported for up to three years. Twelve additional transfer students were also incorporated into the appropriate cohorts during the program, each receiving two years of support. The Scholars came from three related STEM majors: Biology, Environmental science, and Animal Behavior, Ecology, & Conservation.

During their time in the Science Scholars program, each student enrolled in two seminars designed to build science literacy & communication (Seminar I; taken at the end of their first year) and career preparation (Seminar II; taken at the beginning of their last year). Additionally, each student became part of the Science Scholars learning community, which included monthly activities throughout the year that nurtured peer interactions and camaraderie. Each cohort was also assigned a mentor from the prior cohort to act a bridge and foster cross-year dialogue and peer support. In their first-year, students also had access to expanded peer-tutoring to cover the most difficult second-year courses. As they proceeded through the program, Scholars had the opportunity to engage in student-faculty research (described below).

Finally, a three-day intensive “BIO BootCamp” was implemented to introduce all incoming BIO/ENV/ABEC students to a set of skills that aided students with their transition to the expectations of college-level STEM coursework, aid in their success during the freshman biology sequence, as well as within their respective majors. These skills included modules on: 1) critical thinking skills to develop the ability to read and to interpret test & homework questions, 2) course survival skills, including note-taking, outlining, and effective study skills, as well as 3) time management strategies to help students balance a full science course-load and still have time for living. Each module consisted of lectures, group discussions/activities, and science enrichment activities. In addition to developing these skills, BootCamp students had the opportunity to interact with many faculty and staff, as well as begin community building with their science-interested peers. This program was offered free of charge to all incoming students enrolled in the first-year introductory biology course. Across seven BootCamp offerings, 415 students chose to participate, 15 of whom later became Science Scholars.

A major goal of the project was to increase recruitment and retention within the targeted STEM majors. In addition to the above supports, we encouraged Science Scholars to participate in faculty-led research opportunities during their time as students. To that end, each Science Scholar had access to fund supporting both independent research projects, as well as support for conference attendance/presentations. Twenty-six of the 35 students participated in research prior to graduation, most of which for all three/two years of program participation. As a whole, 34 of 35 students were retained at the university, and 32 have graduated with a STEM degree.

As part of the project, we sought to adapt “embeddedness theory” from organizational research and apply it to STEM education, looking at student’s match between their own interests with those in their major (“Fit”), their connections to other students and to the university (“Links”), and the expected losses should the student leave their major or the university (“Sacrifice”). In brief we found that as a student’s embeddedness increased, their intentions to remain in their chosen major and, perhaps more importantly, intentions to remain at their institution and graduate also significantly increased. The development of this scale and its specific application to smaller institutions (“Development of a Brief College Embeddedness Scale”) was published in the Journal of College Student Retention: Research, Theory & Practice (doi: 10.1177/15210251231217094)

In summary, of the 35 students who participated in the Canisius Science Scholars Program over the seven-year period of the grant, 32 graduated with a major in the sciences in four years, with two additional graduates expected after the date of this outcome report, leading to an expected 97% graduation rate. This compares favorably with the six-year graduation rate at the university of 66%. Moreover, despite the COVID-19 pandemic significantly disrupting the university from Spring 2020-Fall 2021, the pandemic was not associated with any decrease in academic outcomes or with embeddedness for the Science Scholars. Finally, approximately 88% of the current graduates (28 of 32) have either entered a career in STEM, a STEM-related field, or have chosen to attend graduate school in a STEM/STEM-related field.


Last Modified: 12/22/2023
Modified by: Andrew D Stewart
